title: Patch Chat 6.12 - Keystones and Catalyst and Marksman Items, Oh My!
body:
Hey all,

Welcome back to Patch Chat! We’re Riot’s Playtest Team, a group of high ranking League players whose job it is to play the hell out of things (lane tests, competitive testing, etc) and give actionable objective feedback to designers.

Every two weeks (concurrent with the release of patch notes), we’re going to be hosting a discussion here on the state of balance on the current patch. **Take this opportunity to ask us any questions about the state of the game.**

It’s been a few weeks of Patch Chat, and we’re still iterating on the format. With three new members starting in the last few weeks, we welcome any feedback about the format of Patch Chat. What do you like about Patch Chat or want to see in the future? What do you hate?

[Patch 6.12](http://leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-612-notes) is being called the ARAM Patch, but it also sees changes to ADC itemization, Youmuu’s Ghostblade, Catalyst items, and Grasp of the Undying.

With sustain for tanks (as well as Catalyst mages like Swain) lower on this patch, and marksman damage upped somewhat, tell us how see the meta shifting!

Curious what it’s like to work as a Riot playtester? Have any questions about the patch as a whole? As usual, feel free to ask any questions about balance or what exactly our job is. We will be around for the next few hours and will try to answer as many questions as possible.

---------------------
**Playtest Team**

* Adam "_Afic_" Cohen
* Preston “_Hinder_” Bunker
* Ben “_Cezium_” Burkhardt
* Shawn “_I Am The IRS_” Currie
* Nicolas “_Gleeb_” Haddad
* Miles “_Daydreamin_” Hoard
* Bao “_Bao_” Lam
* Mattias “_Gentleman Gustaf_” Lehman
* Nicholas “_Nickwu_” Smith
* Blake “_S0be_” Soberanis
* Trevor “_ThEntropist_” Thernes

All feedback is good feedback. And emotional feedback is very good at helping to flag what champions need reworks. If a champion (such as Zed) on paper and in testing labs sucks: his winrate is garbage and is borderline Urgot tier, then what you've discovered is that it is the kit that is the balancing problem.

Look, arguing with people saying "your feelings on this champion are wrong, he is actually bad" is never going to work, and you just paint yourself as somebody in the realm of "I am a game designer, and thus I know better than you." And nobody wants you to do that. Firstly, we know that's not what you mean. But secondly and mainly, it is just as non-helpful to the conversation as the people you're arguing with. Just because you say Zed is weak and people are wrong to think he is banworthy, does not contribute to solving the problem of the differential between perceived strength and actual strength. All you're doing with those statements is fanning an anti-riot sentiment where people believe there to be some "We know better than the players" mindset.

It doesn't help the conversation and I think you can do better.

I think quite a few of us are blowing certain topics out of proportion as well as letting emotions hinder progress, and this isn't doing anything for the community. You've been given a great opportunity to collaborate/discuss with respected employees from Riot. So, I think it would be wise to take a second and ask yourself if what you're posting is going to fuel a positive discussion... and will it affect the appropriate changes positively that you want to see in League of Legends.  Before you ask a question, contemplate each question in relation to every other champion existing now and every match possible from start to finish.  I think that is what Riot THENTROPIST is referring to with Zed. His win rate is lower for many reasons, some of which are from his nerf, translating into diminished game tactics involving him (roaming, itemization in terms of gold efficiency, etc...).  So, statistically speaking, it is much more difficult to win with zed due to community feedback... good or otherwise.  Mechanically speaking, Zed's abilities allow him to be almost unrivaled to average players much like the damage in Katarina's burst if she manages to catch you.  This game highly considers reaction time, but it should consider reaction time and tactics for the average community/player.  Zed is a champion the average community has trouble tactically beating due to the average player's reaction time and potential with tactics.  In my opinion, the problem is not the champs. The problem is traced back to when you first play this game... the tutorials.  I believe if there were a much more detailed tutorial that could teach players game mechanics and punishing an opponent for grabbing cs, laning phase, structure of kiting, and we had open access to this material on a hosted Riot website... knowledge on how to play against a pk/roaming champion like Zed would allow us to shift our focus on more pressing issues like where does Riot intend on shifting the meta, why, and what do we have to look forward to seeing in the near future?  Remember, Riot employees should be respected even when you are so frustrated you could just slam your computer on the ground... Civility, eloquence, and structure will make Riot create changes more quickly and favorably for players like us. Thank you, Riot, for your efforts.

I think I can elaborate on this one. I play almost exclusively mages in mid, and have been around since Fizz's release (god those days were awful). Never before have I felt this "forced" into linear build paths as a mage before. The first few items most mages are forced to build are Catalyst, Tear, Seeker's, Lost Chapter, or Negatron Cloak. Out of these items, 2 of the give AP. And out of the items they build into, few of them give over 60 AP when completed.

Sure between Elder Dragon/other things, overall AP MIGHT (rng on dragons is not something I particularly feel is fun...) be higher at full builds, but prior to that at almost all stages it feels like mages do less damage. CDR itemization really just kind of hides this problem. Because every item (not really) has CDR you can throw spells more, but to throw more spells you need mana. But to get mana you need to give up on higher AP items.... So it's kinda a vicious cycle in midlane where nobody ever really feels good about anything they're building. Seeker's armguard is pretty much obsolete when your opponent gets serrated, and the double tap nerf to Zhonya's feels especially bad. 

Across the board, you're right. AP is probably technically higher at full build. But I bet (and you can look at numbers that we cannot) that until roughly level 14+, at all stages of the game, AP is lower across the board. (meanwhile the only champions that have had changes to their ratios to compensate for all these item changes were mages who got updated.... meanwhile the rest of the cast sits on S1-5 ratios.)

I think the point is how low base AP is at the moment and how sometimes even high-end burst mages can feel underpowered because they don't get enough raw AP in their first set of items to fuel their burst combos causing them to be unable to burst down priority targets by a very small margin on several occasions. Cases like this include Brand, where despite having massive AOE dmg, has low AP scalings and requires too much set up to fully execute his combo in a teamfight and making him nigh-useless ir if he's even slightly behind on the item curve. On the other end of the spectrum this causes mages with either massive scalings but slow/delayed combos such as Anivia and Viktor, or sustained damage mages like Swain and Azir, or even mages with mixed scalings such as Vlad to step in and fill the void left by pure burst mages.

That also creates an over-reliance on AP multipliers like Deathcap and Void Staff, both items that have wonky buildpaths and stiff combine costs, or on the AP multipliers of Infernal and Blue Buff which are conditional on too many outside factors (dragon and buff steals and even the willingness of the jungler to give the blue to the mid laner). When comparing AP casters to their AD counterparts, they have a much heavier reliance on raw AP, unlike AD who can scale via armor pen, crit or attack speed, thus not requiring as much raw AD, unless you are Jhin ofc. In a nutshell it's not satisfying to have your core power curve be reliant on external factors.

Also the fact that even with stacking items, AP amounts won't scale up as much due to the mana and AP nerfs to ROA, causing a class of champions who already had troubles scaling into lategame, even more issues in scaling into lategame and creating an issue where the powerspike gained from a ROA/Seraph's fully stacked doesn't grant the same satisfying powerspike it did before. Case and point of the former, Twisted Fate who went ROA to get a potent spike and be more relevant mid-lategame. Case and point of the latter, Karthus, who went double stacking and ended up at full build with over 1000 AP, which generated a visible impact on his ultimate lategame. In other words the end game reward for the risk you took with going with stacking items isn't quite as good/satisfying from a pure damage perspective. 

A simple point to this would be to somewhat increase AP amounts on basic items and heavily increase AP on stacking items but lower the AP multiplier passives like Rababon and Void Staff (and perhaps streamline it's buildpath/lower its combine cost) so that mages can get their powerspikes in a more satisfying/organic/steadier way.

So mages have to rely on a temporary buff whose timer is known to everyone and a random dragon spawning? Ap values are lower with the item update. However cdr is plentiful to the point where its almost harder to not hit the cap or exceed it than be below it.  This is fine for mages that are utility focused but for mages more centered on damage  especially in a single rotation its quite noticeable the loss in damage.

So, Zed has over an 85% ban rate in Plat+, and least over 60+% at all other levels.

That should make it really obvious that people really *do not like playing against him.*

When is he going to get some actual proper changes to bring him to a state where people can actually bear to play against him?
Adding an indicator around his shadows does nothing to make him less oppressive.

The patch notes say that "Zed's inherent frustration is intended".  How can a champion that is intentionally frustrating to play against be justified as anything but bad game design?

Sure, dying can feel frustrating, but it should always feel fair - like you died because you made a mistake or the other player played better than you.
No one feels outplayed by Zed.  He does not feel fair to play against.  (There are a few other champions with the same problem.)

His laning phase is completely oppressive.
He can easily push most mana users out of lane.
He has strong waveclear and incredibly tower-killing ability - on a champion who is supposed to be designed to kill enemy squishies.
He has practically no costs - meaning he can stay in lane forever.
He is AD, making him much freer to take defensive runes, since AD does not conflict with MR, unlike AP.
He can rush Hexdrinker which makes him almost impossible to kill (while mages have no equivalently strong item to build against him.)

His assassination is top-notch and has very little counterplay.  He gets in range, and then either the Zed player hits all his skills, or he doesn't.  There's little space for his opponent to make skillful plays to avoid or reduce his damage, except if they have instant/skillshot hard CC or a shield.

He is relatively safe, both in lane (shadow escape) and even more so in all-ins.  His tiny 1-second window does almost nothing to make him vulnerable for someone with an untargetability-gapcloser and near-instant escape.  He can apply all of his damage in 1 second and then run away with almost no opportunity of counterattack.


In short: he is really strong at laning.  He is really strong at taking towers.  He is decent at roaming.  He is very good at assassination.  He can escape easily.  The item system also favours him heavily, especially against mana users.

People hate having to deal with that.  Even in games where you win, you have to suffer being miserable for the entire laning phase until he finally starts to fall off a bit in teamfights (if he hasn't managed to get fed too much by then, and your team brought enough tanks.)

Uh, no.  Armour is near-universally lower than Magic Resist at level 1.  All champions have at least 30 MR at level 1, some (melee champions with scaling MR) hae slightly more.  Only Rammus alone has more than 30 armour at level 1.  Most champions have below 20.

However, armour scales on all champions, and MR only scales on some (again, melee champions.)
Most ranged champions don't break 30 armour until they are roughly level 5, or higher (melees tend to gain it faster.)

Now, runes.  A full page of armour runes yields 9.0 armour.  A full set of flat MR runes yields 12 armour.  That means that MR runes are 33% more effective than armour runes.

Let's pick some random examples: Taliyah, Ziggs, and Zed.
At level 6, Taliyah with armour runes has 40.9 armour.
Zed with MR runes has 49 MR
Ziggs with armour runes has 43.6 armour.

There's also some argument to be made that MR is more effective than armour, because mages have a burst damage pattern, meaning that MR is an exact reduction to their damage output until their next rotation, while champions with sustained damage can continue dealing damage for longer.  Zed falls somewhere between the two, but can certainly use his powerful autoattacks to supplement his damage.

If you want Trynd to be less frustrating to fight against (and the ult is off limits obviously) then replace mocking shout's false choice with something else.

I've played over 6 thousand games with Trynd, and any die-hard Trynd main will tell you that most of what makes him both frustrating to play against and very binary is the fact that mocking shout is probably the most unhealthy ability in the game. If you stay and fight, your ability to fight is debuffed; if you try to run, both your ability to run and fight are debuffed.

Trynd can use his dance animation, which starts nearly the same as his mocking shout cast animation to force you to turn around multiple times while running away from him. Turning around a bunch of times in anticipation of the actual shout is tantamount to be slowed in the first place. It provides a false choice, has a ton of hidden power, causes Trynd to win damage trades that he shouldn't, and on top of that forces Trynd into a binary pattern of thrive or starve.

Yasuo's windwall is about as frustrating but is strictly superior from a design point of view because it doesn't make yasuo feast or famine-- its utility is game changing no matter what the score is, and you can position and play around it without making yasuo feel worthless. It allows him to make fights more complex, and meshes with the mobility of his kit, which is designed to thrive in complex fights. Yasuo generally cannot apply reliable damage to you without coming out from behind the wall, so its long lasting utility is gated in fights for which yasuo is the aggressor.

I've said this before, but because people who don't play Trynd day in and day out don't understand what makes him tick, and because Undying Rage is much "noisier" than mocking shout, people cast it aside: if mocking shout were replaced with something that is actually functional for league of legends, Trynd would be half as frustrating to fight and twice as fair.
